sen.j: 籠神社（このじんじゃ、こもりじんじゃ）は、京都府宮津市の天橋立の近くにある神社である。
sen.e: Kono-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located near Amanohashidate in Miyazu City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Kono-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located near Amanohashidate in Miyazu City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Kono-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located near Amanohashidate in Miyazu City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 式内社（名神大社）、丹後国一宮で、旧社格は国幣中社（現、神社本庁の別表神社）。
sen.e: It is listed in the Engishiki Shrine Name Book (as a Myojin Taisha), was the supreme shrine of Tango Prefecture and was formerly ranked as a Kokuhei-chusha (it is presently classified as a Beppyo-jinja 'special independent shrine' by the Association of Shinto Shrines.

It is listed in the Engishiki Shrine Name Book (as a Myojin Taisha), and was the supreme shrine of Tango Prefecture and was formerly ranked as a Kokuhei-chusha (it is presently classified as a Beppyo-jinja 'special independent shrine' by the Association of Shinto Shrines.

It is Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers)) (Myojin Taisha (shrines that enshrine gods known as Myojin)), the supreme shrine of Tango Province, and formerly ranked as a Kokuhei-chusha (middle-sized national shrine) (presently classified as a Beppyo-jinja (special independent shrine) by the Association of Shinto Shrines).
sen.cmt: 「式内社」のローマ字と延喜式と「名神大社」の英訳を補足しました。

sen.j: 元伊勢の一つであり、元伊勢籠神社とも称する。
sen.e: As one of the Moto Ise, it is also known as Moto Ise Kono-jinja.
As one of the Moto Ise, it is also known as Moto Ise Kono-jinja.
As one of the Moto Ise (shrines or places where the deities of Ise Jingu Shrine were once enshrined), it is also known as Moto Ise Kono-jinja.
sen.cmt: 「元伊勢」の英訳を補足しました。

sen.j: 別称 元伊勢根本宮、内宮元宮、籠守大権現、籠宮大明神。
sen.e: The shrine is also known by the names 'Moto Ise Konpon-gu', 'Naiku Gengu', Komori Daigongen' and 'Konomiya Daimyojin'.
The shrine is also known by the names 'Moto Ise Konpon-gu', 'Naiku Gengu', Komori Daigongen' and 'Konomiya Daimyojin'.
The shrine is also known by the names Moto Ise Konpon-gu, Naiku Gengu, Komori Daigongen and Konomiya Daimyojin.

sen.j: 祭神
sen.e: Enshrined Deity
Enshrined Deity
Enshrined Deities

sen.j: 彦火明命（ひこほあかりのみこと、別名：天火明命、天照御魂神、天照国照彦火明命、饒速日命）を主祭神とし、豊受大神（とようけのおおかみ、別名：御饌津神）、天照大神（あまてらすおおかみ）、海神（わたつみのかみ）、天水分神（あめのみくまりのかみ）を相殿に祀る。
sen.e: The main enshrined deity is Hiko Hoakari no Mikoto (also known as Ameno Hoakari no Mikoto, Amaterasu Mitama no Kami, Amateru Kuniteruhiko Hoakari no Mikoto and Nigihayahi no Mikoto), which is enshrined along with Toyouke no Ookami (also known as Miketsu Kami), Amaterasu Ookami, Watatsumi no kami and Ameno Mikumari no Kami.

The main enshrined deity is Hiko Hoakari no Mikoto (also known as Ameno Hoakari no Mikoto, Amaterasu Mitama no Kami, Amateru Kuniteruhiko Hoakari no Mikoto and Nigihayahi no Mikoto), which is enshrined along with Toyouke no Ookami (also known as Miketsu Kami), Amaterasu Ookami, Watatsumi no kami and Ameno Mikumari no Kami.

The main enshrined deity is Hiko Hoakari no Mikoto (also known as Ameno Hoakari no Mikoto, Amaterasu Mitama no Kami, Amateru Kuniteruhiko Hoakari no Mikoto and Nigihayahi no Mikoto), which is enshrined along with Toyouke no Okami (also known as Miketsu Kami), Amaterasu Okami, Watatsumi no kami and Ameno Mikumari no Kami.

sen.j: 祭神には諸説あり、『丹後国式社證実考』などではイザナギ(いざなぎ)としている。
sen.e: There are various legends regarding the main enshrined deity and texts including "Tangonokuni Shikishashou Jikko" claim it to be Izanagi.
There are various legends regarding the main enshrined deity and texts including "Tangonokuni Shikishashou Jikko" claim it to be Izanagi.

There are various legends regarding the main enshrined deity and texts including "Tangonokuni Shikishasho Jikko" (Lectures on Tango Shrines Noted in the Engishiki) claim it to be Izanagi no Mikoto (one of the two deities principally responsible for the formation of the world).
sen.cmt: 「丹後国式社證実考」「イザナギ」の英訳を補足しました。

sen.j: これは、伊弉諾尊が天に登るための梯子が倒れて天橋立になったという伝承があるためである。
sen.e: This arises from the legend that the ladder used by Izanagi no Mikoto to ascend to the heavens collapsed and became Amanohashidate.
This arises from the legend that the ladder used by Izanagi no Mikoto to ascend to the heavens collapsed and became Amanohashidate.
This arises from the legend that the ladder, used by Izanagi no Mikoto to ascend to the heavens, collapsed and became Amanohashidate.
sen.cmt: ピリオドを補足しました。

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 社伝によれば、元々真名井原の地（現在の境外摂社・奥宮真名井神社）に豊受大神が鎮座し、匏宮（よさのみや、与佐宮とも）と称されていた。
sen.e: Shrine legend tells that Toyouke no Ookami was originally enshrined at Manaihara (now the site of the external sessha (secondary shrine) Okumiya Manai-jinja Shrine) and the shrine was named Yosano Miya.

Shrine legend tells that Toyouke no Ookami was originally enshrined at Manaihara (now the site of the external sessha (secondary shrine) Okumiya Manai-jinja Shrine) and the shrine was named Yosano Miya.

The shrine legend tells that Toyouke no Okami was originally enshrined at Manaihara (now the site of the external sessha (auxiliary shrine (dedicated to a deity close-related to that of a main shrine)) Okumiya Manai-jinja Shrine) and the shrine was named Yosano Miya.
sen.cmt: 「Ookami」→「Okami」とし「摂社」の英訳を補足しました。

sen.j: 『神道五部書』の一つの「豊受大神御鎮座本紀」によれば、崇神天皇の時代、天照大神が大和笠縫邑から与佐宮に移り、豊受大神から御饌物を受けていた。
sen.e: According to 'Toyouke no Ookami Gochinza Hongi', one of the "Shinto Gobusho" (5 books of Shinto), Amaterasu Ookami relocated to Yosano Miya from Yamato Kasanui no Mura during the reign of Emperor Sujin and received a sacred food offering from Toyouke no Ookami.

According to 'Toyouke no Ookami Gochinza Hongi', one of the "Shinto Gobusho" (5 books of Shinto), Amaterasu Ookami relocated to Yosano Miya from Yamato Kasanui no Mura during the reign of Emperor Sujin and received a sacred food offering from Toyouke no Ookami.

According to 'Toyouke no Okami Gochinza Hongi', one of the "Shinto Gobusho" (5 books of Shinto), Amaterasu Okami relocated to Yosanomiya from Yamato Kasanui no Mura during the reign of Emperor Sujin and received a sacred food offering from Toyouke no Okami.

sen.j: 4年後、天照大神は伊勢へ移り、後に豊受大神も伊勢神宮へ移った。
sen.e: Four years later, Amaterasu Ookami moved to Ise and, later still, Toyouke no Ookami moved to Ise-jingu Shrine.
Four years later, Amaterasu Ookami moved to Ise and, later still, Toyouke no Ookami moved to Ise-jingu Shrine.
Four years later, Amaterasu Okami moved to Ise and, later, Toyouke no Okami moved to Ise-jingu Shrine.

sen.j: これによって、当社を「元伊勢」という。
sen.e: It is due to this that the shrine became known as 'Moto Ise'.
It is due to this that the shrine became known as 'Moto Ise'.
Due to above, the shrine became known as 'Moto Ise.'
sen.cmt: 「It is due to this that」→「Due to above」とし、ピリオドの位置を変えました。

sen.j: 養老3年（719年）、真名井原から現在地に遷座して主祭神を彦火明命とし、豊受・天照両神を相殿に祀り、社名を籠宮に改めた。
sen.e: In the year 719, the shrine was relocated from Manaihara to its current location, Hiko Hoakari no Mikoto was enshrined as the main deity alongside Toyouke and Amaterasu, and the name of the shrine was changed to Kono Miya.

In the year 719, the shrine was relocated from Manaihara to its current location, and Hiko Hoakari no Mikoto was enshrined as the main deity alongside Toyouke and Amaterasu, and the name of the shrine was changed to Kono Miya.

In 719, the shrine was relocated from Manaihara to its current location, and Hiko Hoakari no Mikoto was enshrined as the main deity alongside Toyouke and Amaterasu, and the name of the shrine was changed to Kono Miya.

sen.j: 真名井原の元の鎮座地は摂社・奥宮真名井神社とされた。
sen.e: The original site at Manaihara is became the sessha (secondary shrine) Okumiya Manai-jinja Shrine.
The original site at Manaihara became the sessha (secondary shrine) Okumiya Manai-jinja Shrine.
The original site at Manaihara became the sessha (secondary shrine) Okumiya Manai-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 後に海神・天水分神が配祀された。
sen.e: Watatsumi no kami and Ameno Mikumari no Kami were later enshrined alongside the existing deities.
Watatsumi no kami and Ameno Mikumari no Kami were later enshrined alongside the existing deities.
Watatsumi no kami and Ameno Mikumari no Kami were later enshrined alongside the existing deities.

sen.j: 祭神が籠に乗って雪の中に現れたから「籠宮」という社名になったという伝承がある。
sen.e: Legend has it that the shrine was named 'Kono Miya' (lit. basket shrine) as the enshrined deities appeared in the snow atop a basket.
Legend has it that the shrine was named 'Kono Miya' (lit. basket shrine) as the enshrined deities appeared in the snow atop a basket.
Legend has it that the shrine was named 'Kono Miya' (lit. basket shrine) as the enshrined deities appeared in the snow on a basket.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳では「丹後国与謝郡 籠神社」と記載され、名神大社に列し、月次・新甞の幣帛に預ると記されている。
sen.e: The Engishiki Shrine Name Book lists the shrine as 'Tango Provence, Yona County, Kono-jinja Shrine', classifies it as a Myojin-taisha Shrine and describes that paper or silk offerings are left each month and during the harvest festival.

The Engishiki Shrine Name Book lists the shrine as 'Tango Provence, Yona County, Kono-jinja Shrine', classifies it as a Myojin-taisha Shrine and describes that paper or silk offerings are left each month and during the harvest festival.

Engishiki Shinmyo Cho (shrine name book under Engishiki) lists the shrine as 'Kono-jinja Shrine of Yona-gun, Tango Provence,' classifies it as a Myojin Taisha, and describes that paper or silk offerings were left each month and during the harvest festival.
sen.cmt: 「延喜式神名帳」のローマ字表記を補足し、表現を少し変えました。

sen.j: 社家の海部氏は、彦火明命を祖とし、当社の創建以来、代々奉斎をしてきたとされ、現在は82代目である。
sen.e: The hereditary line of Shinto priests of the Amabe family who believe Hiko Hoakari no Mikoto to be their ancestor and have conducted services at the shrine since its founding are now in their 82nd generation.

The hereditary line of Shinto priests of the Amabe family who believe Hiko Hoakari no Mikoto to be their ancestor and have conducted services at the shrine since its founding are now in their 82nd generation.

The Amabe clan of Shake (family of Shinto priests serving a shrine on a hereditary basis), who are believed Hiko Hoakari no Mikoto to be their ancestor, has conducted services at the shrine since its founding and now they are in their 82nd generation.
sen.cmt: 「The Amabe family」→「The Amabe clan」とし、表現を変えました。

sen.j: 4代目の倭宿禰命は神武東征の際に亀に乗って神武天皇の前に現れ、大和国へ先導した。
sen.e: During the Jinmu Tosei, 4th generation priest Yamatono Shukune no Mikoto appeared riding a tortoise in front of Emperor Jinmu and guided him to Yamato Province.
During the Jinmu Tosei, 4th generation priest Yamatono Shukune no Mikoto appeared riding a tortoise in front of Emperor Jinmu and guided him to Yamato Province.
During the eastward expedition of Jinmu, 4th generation priest Yamato no Shukune no Mikoto appeared riding a tortoise in front of Emperor Jinmu and guided him to Yamato Province.
sen.cmt: 「神武東征」の訳を変更しました。

sen.j: 「海部氏系図」が国宝に指定されている。
sen.e: The 'Anabe Family Tree' has been designated a National Treasure.
The 'Anabe Family Tree' has been designated a National Treasure.
The genealogy of the Amabe clan' has been designated a National Treasure.

sen.j: 施設
sen.e: Layout
Layout
Subsidiary Shrines
sen.cmt: 配置ではないので、訳語を変えました。

sen.j: 境外社
sen.e: Subsidiary Shrine External to the Main Precinct
Subsidiary Shrine External to the Main Precinct
Subsidiary Shrine External to the Main Precinct

sen.j: 本社の北東約400mの所に、当社の元の鎮座地である奥宮真名井神社（まないじんじゃ）がある（）。
sen.e: The shrine's original location of Manai-jinja Shrine sits approximately 400 meters northeast of the main shrine.
The shrine's original location of Manai-jinja Shrine sits approximately 400 meters northeast of the main shrine.
Manai-jinja Shrine, Okumiya (the rear shrine), is located in the site of approximately 400 meters northeast of the main shrine, where Kono-jinja Shrine were originally located.
sen.cmt: 「奥宮」訳を補足、スペル修正、全体の表現を変えました。

sen.j: 本殿はなく、拝殿の裏に2つの磐座がある。
sen.e: It does not have a main hall but there are two iwakura (rocks in which kami dwell) behind the worship hall.
It does not have a main hall but there are two iwakura (rocks in which kami dwell) behind the worship hall.
It does not have a main hall but there are two iwakura (rocks in which kami dwell) behind the worship hall.

sen.j: 右の磐座主座は豊受大神を主祭神とし、相殿にミズハノメ、彦火火出見尊、神代五代神を祀る。
sen.e: The main iwakura or the right enshrines the main deity Toyouke no Ookami as well as Mizuhanome, Hoko Hoho Demi no Mikoto and Kamiyo Godaishin.
The main iwakura or the right enshrines the main deity Toyouke no Ookami as well as Mizuhanome, Hoko Hoho Demi no Mikoto and Kamiyo Godaishin.

The main iwakura on the right enshrines the main deity Toyouke no Okami as well as Mizuhanome, Hoko Hoho Demi no Mikoto and Kamiyo Godaishin (神代五代神, literally, five deities in the Japanese Myth period).
sen.cmt: 「or」→「on」、「神代五代神」は定訳不明なので、直訳と日本語を追記しました。

sen.j: 左の磐座西座は天照大神を主祭神としイザナギ・イザナミを配祀する。
sen.e: The western iwakura on the left enshrines the main deity Amaterasu Ookami as well as Izanagi no Mikoto and Izanami no Mikoto.
The western iwakura on the left enshrines the main deity Amaterasu Ookami as well as Izanagi no Mikoto and Izanami no Mikoto.
The western iwakura on the left enshrines the main deity Amaterasu Okami as well as Izanagi no Mikoto and Izanami no Mikoto.

sen.j: 真名井という社名は、境内に「真名井の水」という神水が涌き出ていることによる。
sen.e: The shrine name 'Manai' derives fom the sacred water known as 'Manai-no-Mizu' that wells up from within the shrine precinct.
The shrine name 'Manai' derives fom the sacred water known as 'Manai-no-Mizu' that wells up from within the shrine precinct.
The shrine name 'Manai' derives from the sacred water known as 'Manai-no-Mizu' that wells up from within the shrine precinct.

sen.j: 境内社
sen.e: Subsidiary Shrine within the Main Precinct
Subsidiary Shrine within the Main Precinct
Subsidiary Shrines within the Main Precinct

sen.j: 摂社 蛭子神社（ホオリ・倭宿彌命））
sen.e: Sessha: Ebisu-jinja Shrine (Hoori, Yamatono Sukuneno Mikoto)
Sessha: Ebisu-jinja Shrine (Hoori, Yamatono Sukuneno Mikoto)
Sessha: Ebisu-jinja Shrine (Ho-ri, Yamatono Sukuneno Mikoto)

sen.j: 摂社 天照皇大神社（天照大神の和魂あるいは荒魂）
sen.e: Sessha: Amaterasu Sumeoo-jinja Shrine (Nigimitama or Aramitama of Amaterasu Ookami)
Sessha: Amaterasu Sumeoo-jinja Shrine (Nigimitama or Aramitama of Amaterasu Ookami)
Sessha: Amaterasu Sumeo-jinja Shrine (Nigimitama (Deity's peaceful soul) or Aramitama (Deity's rough soul) of Amaterasu Okami)

sen.j: 摂社 真名井稲荷神社（ウカノミタマ・ウケモチ・豊受比売） -- 明治末期まで奥宮真名井神社に鎮座していたものを、1991年に本社境内に再建した
sen.e: Sessha: Manai Inari-jinja Shrine (Ukanomitama, Ukemochi, Toyouke Hime): This shrine stood at Okumiya Manai-jinja Shrine until the end of the Meiji period and was rebuilt within the precinct of the main shrine in 1991.

Sessha: Manai Inari-jinja Shrine (Ukanomitama, Ukemochi, Toyouke Hime): This shrine stood at Okumiya Manai-jinja Shrine until the end of the Meiji period and was rebuilt within the precinct of the main shrine in 1991.

Sessha: Manai Inari-jinja Shrine (Ukanomitama, Ukemochi, Toyouke Hime): This shrine stood at Okumiya Manai-jinja Shrine until the end of the Meiji period and was rebuilt within the precinct of the main shrine in 1991.

sen.j: 末社 春日大名神社（春日神）
sen.e: Massha: Kasuga Daimyojinja Shrine (Kasuga no Kami)
Massha: Kasuga Daimyojinja Shrine (Kasuga no Kami)
Massha (subordinate shrine) : Kasuga Daimyo-jinja Shrine (Kasuga no Kami)
sen.cmt: 「末社」の英訳を補足しました。

sen.j: 末社 猿田彦神社（サルタヒコ）
sen.e: Massha: Sarutahoko-jinja Shrine (Sarutahiko)
Massha: Sarutahoko-jinja Shrine (Sarutahiko)
Massha: Sarutahiko-jinja Shrine (Sarutahiko (an earthly deity))
